Description: Rim and body sherd of Attic red-figured pottery bell-krater with handle scar on left; interior glazed black with reserved band at junction of body and rim; exterior: laurel wreath on rim; reserved band at junction of rim and body; trace of ovolo ornament around handle root; to right, red-figure symposium scene: bearded man and youth reclining to left on couch; the former wears wreath with berries in added white with yellow wash and looks right, holding up a kylix with right fore-finger as if playing kottabos; the youth, wearing similar wreath, reaches out his right hand, seemingly touching the man’s head; both figures resting with left arm on decorated cushions, lower bodies covered with himatia (dilute brown for shading in interior of himatia at waist level); to right, part of white right arm of woman; below couch (part of leg on left), part of low table with food in white with yellow wash; above figures, bunches of grapes (white with yellow wash) and white leaves.
Curator's comments: For parallels, see the bell krater, Vienna, Kunsthistorishe Museum 1010 (CVA Vienna 3, pl. 135) dated 360-350 BC.
Bibliographic references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum (F36)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0220) (Phase 1)
